audio.transcript: Some parents have found that signing to their babies is a great way to start early communication. Research has been devoted specifically to baby sign language and teaching hearing babies to use signs before they are able to speak.

Researchers have discovered that babies can invent their own signs, including indicators and characterizing signs. Indicators, such as pointing, are used by the child to refer to people, places, and things. Characterizing signs are used to refer to actions, such as eating, or to the qualities of an object.

Researchers Linda Acredolo and Susan Goodwyn, authors of Baby Signs, explain that because babies can invent their own signs, perhaps babies can use signs for concepts before they can speak. For babies who have communication issues, signing can be extremely helpful because it gives the child an ability to express their needs.

Acredolo and Goodwyn found the following advantages to teaching babies these kinds of signs: Parents reported enjoying an additional way to communicate with their children. Babies seemed less frustrated because they could communicate their ideas. And babies who used signs were advanced in language, cognitive status, and in play. These babies, on average, knew about 50 more real words by age 2, compared to their non-signing peers.
